questions.text: Flower vase appearance on IVP is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The "flower vase appearance," or sometimes "bouquet of flowers" or "handshake sign," on an Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) is a classic descriptive finding associated with a horseshoe kidney. A horseshoe kidney is a congenital anomaly where the two kidneys are fused, typically at their lower poles, across the midline of the body. This fusion often results in an abnormal rotation and medial deviation of the lower pole calyces (the cup-like structures that collect urine in the kidney). When contrast dye fills these medially oriented calyces, their arrangement can resemble the splayed form of a flower vase, with the calyces pointing inwards towards the midline rather than laterally, and the ureters often originating anteriorly. This characteristic presentation is a key diagnostic clue for horseshoe kidney on imaging studies like IVP. The other options are incorrect because their typical appearances on IVP do not match the "flower vase" description: B. Polycystic kidney: Polycystic kidney disease, particularly autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), on IVP shows greatly enlarged kidneys with multiple, variably sized cysts. These cysts distort and stretch the renal collecting system, leading to a characteristic "spider leg" or "Swiss cheese" appearance due to the compression and elongation of the calyces and infundibula by the cysts, which is distinctly different from a "flower vase" shape. C. Pyonephrosis: Pyonephrosis refers to an infected and obstructed kidney, often filled with pus. On IVP, findings would primarily involve signs of obstruction such as hydronephrosis (dilated renal pelvis and calyces) and a significantly reduced or absent excretion of contrast medium by the affected kidney due to severe renal damage and obstruction. While the collecting system is distorted, it does not typically take on a "flower vase" appearance. D. Congenital megaureter: A congenital megaureter is characterized by an abnormally wide and often tortuous ureter, frequently associated with hydronephrosis due to vesicoureteral reflux or obstruction. The IVP would demonstrate a dilated ureter and potentially a dilated collecting system in the kidney, but the appearance of the calyces themselves would not be described as a "flower vase."

questions.text: In intravenous pyelography, one contracted kidney indicates:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chronic pyelonephritis. In intravenous pyelography (IVP), a contracted kidney is most commonly seen in chronic pyelonephritis, which is a long-standing infection of the kidney leading to progressive scarring, fibrosis, and renal atrophy. The affected kidney becomes small, irregular, and deformed due to repeated episodes of infection and inflammation. IVP findings typically show a small, contracted kidney with asymmetry, irregular calyces, cortical thinning, and sometimes areas of scarring. The renal function may also be impaired, leading to delayed contrast excretion. Chronic pyelonephritis often results from vesicoureteral reflux (reflux nephropathy) or recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs), leading to progressive renal damage. This condition is usually unilateral, which is why IVP reveals one contracted kidney. Incorrect Options: Hydronephrosis (Option A): Hydronephrosis occurs due to obstruction of urine flow, leading to progressive dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces. On IVP, the kidney appears enlarged with dilated calyces and a thin renal cortex, rather than contracted. This is the opposite of the findings in chronic pyelonephritis. Polycystic Kidney (Option B): Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) leads to bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple fluid-filled cysts. IVP findings include distorted calyces and large kidneys, not a small, contracted kidney. Chronic Glomerulonephritis (Option C): In chronic glomerulonephritis, both kidneys usually undergo bilateral symmetrical contraction due to progressive glomerular damage and fibrosis. Unlike chronic pyelonephritis, which is often unilateral, glomerulonephritis affects both kidneys equally, leading to small, smooth, and symmetrically shrunken kidneys on IVP.

questions.text: Absolute contraindication for IVP is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Idiosyncrasy to iodine. In intravenous pyelography (IVP), iodinated contrast media are used to visualize the urinary tract. An absolute contraindication is a condition where the procedure must not be performed under any circumstances due to the high risk of severe complications. Idiosyncrasy to iodine refers to a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to iodinated contrast agents, which can lead to life-threatening hypersensitivity reactions, including bronchospasm, hypotension, laryngeal edema, and cardiovascular collapse. Because of this risk, IVP must be avoided in patients with a known iodine allergy, and alternative imaging methods like ultrasound or MRI should be considered instead. Incorrect Options: Multiple Myeloma (Option B): Multiple myeloma is associated with kidney dysfunction due to light chain deposition and an increased risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. While IVP should be used with extreme caution in multiple myeloma patients, it is not an absolute contraindication. Adequate hydration and alternative imaging methods, such as non-contrast CT, may be preferable. Raised Blood Urea (Option C): High blood urea indicates renal impairment, and contrast agents can further worsen kidney function. While this is a relative contraindication, IVP can sometimes still be performed with proper pre-hydration and monitoring. However, alternative imaging like ultrasound or MRI is often preferred in renal failure patients. Bilateral Ureteric Obstruction (Option D): In bilateral ureteric obstruction, the contrast may not be excreted properly, making IVP less effective. While this limits the diagnostic value of IVP, it is not an absolute contraindication. Instead, caution is advised, and non-invasive imaging methods like ultrasound or MR urography may be better choices. All of the Above (Option E): While the other conditions require caution, they are not absolute contraindications. The only absolute contraindication among the listed options is idiosyncrasy to iodine, making Option A the correct answer.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for assessing a child with vesicoureteric reflux is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG). Micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG) is the investigation of choice for assessing vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) in children. VUR is a condition in which urine flows backward from the bladder into the ureters and kidneys, increasing the risk of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and renal scarring. MCUG is a fluoroscopic imaging study where contrast is instilled into the bladder via a catheter, and real-time X-ray images are taken during voiding (micturition). This test is essential for diagnosing the presence, severity (grading), and extent of reflux, making it the most accurate test for VUR. Additionally, MCUG helps detect bladder abnormalities and posterior urethral valves, which are common causes of urinary obstruction in children. Incorrect Options: Antegrade IVP (Option A): Antegrade IVP (or antegrade pyelography) is performed by injecting contrast directly into the renal pelvis via percutaneous access. It is primarily used to evaluate upper urinary tract obstructions or post-surgical urinary diversions, but it does not assess reflux from the bladder to the ureters. Retrograde IVP (Option B): Retrograde IVP (or retrograde pyelography) involves injecting contrast into the ureters via cystoscopy to visualize the upper urinary tract. This test is mainly used for detecting ureteral strictures, stones, or tumors, but it does not assess reflux, making it unsuitable for diagnosing VUR. Cystoscopy (Option D): Cystoscopy is a direct visual examination of the bladder and urethra using an endoscope. While it is useful for detecting bladder tumors, strictures, and urethral anomalies, it does not evaluate VUR. Moreover, it is invasive and not typically used as a first-line investigation for reflux in children.

questions.text: Nephrogram phase of IVP is because of dye in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Proximal convoluted tubules. The nephrogram phase of intravenous pyelography (IVP) occurs shortly after contrast injection, typically within 1–3 minutes. During this phase, the contrast is present within the renal parenchyma, particularly in the proximal convoluted tubules (PCT) of the nephrons. The contrast is filtered by the glomeruli and then absorbed by the tubular system, creating a uniform dense opacification of the renal cortex. This phase is essential for assessing renal perfusion, tubular function, and early signs of renal pathology such as acute kidney injury, renal artery stenosis, or cortical scarring. Any delay or asymmetry in the nephrogram phase can indicate conditions like hydronephrosis, obstruction, or renal ischemia. Incorrect Options: Renal Pelvis (Option B): The renal pelvis is part of the excretory system where urine is collected before passing into the ureters. The contrast reaches the renal pelvis later during the pyelogram phase (7–15 minutes post-injection). This phase helps visualize hydronephrosis, stones, or ureteric obstructions, but it does not contribute to the nephrogram phase. Nephron (Option C): While the nephron (glomerulus + tubules) is the functional unit of the kidney, the nephrogram phase specifically occurs due to contrast accumulation in the proximal convoluted tubules rather than in the entire nephron. The nephron includes structures like the glomerulus, loop of Henle, and distal tubule, but only the PCT is responsible for the dense opacification seen in the nephrogram phase. Collecting Tubules (Option D): The collecting tubules are involved in the final concentration and transport of urine but do not contribute significantly to the nephrogram phase. The contrast reaches the collecting system in the delayed excretory phase, not the early nephrogram phase.

questions.text: Contraindications to IVP is/are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above. Intravenous pyelography (IVP) is a diagnostic imaging procedure that uses iodinated contrast to visualize the urinary tract. However, it has several contraindications due to the potential risks associated with contrast media. The major contraindications include: Idiosyncrasy to iodine (Option A): This refers to an allergic reaction to iodinated contrast agents, which can range from mild skin rashes to severe anaphylactic shock with bronchospasm, hypotension, and cardiovascular collapse. This is an absolute contraindication for IVP, and alternative imaging methods like ultrasound or MRI should be considered. Multiple myeloma (Option B): Multiple myeloma patients are at high risk of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) due to the accumulation of light chains in the kidneys, which can lead to acute kidney injury (myeloma kidney). IV contrast can worsen renal function in these patients, making IVP a relative contraindication. However, if absolutely necessary, adequate hydration and pre-procedural renal function assessment are required. Diabetes (Option C): Diabetic patients, especially those with diabetic nephropathy or on metformin, are at risk for contrast-induced nephropathy. The contrast can further impair renal function, leading to acute kidney injury. In patients taking metformin, there is a risk of lactic acidosis if renal function deteriorates. IVP should be avoided or performed with extreme caution, with pre-hydration and renal function monitoring.

questions.text: Micturating cystourethrogram is not used in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Renal tumours. Micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG) is a specialized imaging technique primarily used to evaluate vesicoureteric reflux (VUR), urinary tract obstruction, and lower urinary tract abnormalities. It involves filling the bladder with contrast and taking fluoroscopic images during voiding to assess the function of the urethra and bladder. However, MCUG is not used to diagnose renal tumors because it does not provide information about renal masses, their size, vascularity, or malignancy potential. Instead, renal tumors are best evaluated using ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI, which provide detailed imaging of renal parenchyma, tumor extent, and metastatic spread. Incorrect Options: Hydronephrosis (Option B): MCUG can help assess hydronephrosis caused by vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) or lower urinary tract obstruction. It helps determine if reflux is the cause of renal pelvis dilation and can differentiate obstructive from non-obstructive causes. Urinary Obstruction (Option C): MCUG is useful for detecting lower urinary tract obstructions, such as posterior urethral valves (PUV) in children or urethral strictures. It helps visualize bladder emptying and any blockage at the urethral or vesicoureteric junction. Recurrent UTI (Option D): In children and adults with recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs), MCUG is commonly performed to detect vesicoureteric reflux, which predisposes patients to repeated infections and renal scarring.

questions.text: Investigation of choice to demonstrate vesicoureteric refiex:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Contrast MCU (Micturating Cystourethrogram). Micturating cystourethrogram (MCU/MCUG) is the investigation of choice to demonstrate vesicoureteric reflux (VUR). This imaging study involves catheterizing the bladder, instilling contrast medium, and taking fluoroscopic images during voiding (micturition). MCU directly visualizes retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters, which is the hallmark of VUR. It also helps in grading the severity of reflux, identifying posterior urethral valves (PUV) in male infants, and detecting bladder or urethral anomalies. Due to its dynamic nature, MCU remains the gold standard for diagnosing VUR, particularly in children with recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and renal scarring. Incorrect Options: IVP (Intravenous Pyelography) (Option A): IVP primarily assesses renal structure and function, and while it may show indirect signs of reflux such as hydronephrosis or dilated ureters, it does not directly visualize reflux. It is less sensitive and less commonly used for VUR diagnosis. Ultrasound (Option B): Ultrasound is non-invasive and useful for detecting hydronephrosis and renal scarring but cannot directly demonstrate VUR. It is often used as a screening tool before proceeding to MCU if VUR is suspected. Cystoscopy (Option D): Cystoscopy is an invasive procedure used to examine the bladder and urethra. It is useful for detecting bladder tumors, strictures, and urethral abnormalities but cannot demonstrate vesicoureteric reflux dynamically.

questions.text: Which of the following is diagnostic of the 'Rim sign' in a nephrogram?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Severe hydronephrosis. The "Rim sign" in a nephrogram refers to a thin rim of enhanced cortical tissue surrounding a non-enhancing central area in the kidney. This occurs in severe hydronephrosis, where the renal parenchyma is significantly thinned due to prolonged obstruction and dilation of the collecting system. In IVP or contrast-enhanced CT, this sign appears as a bright outer rim of renal tissue with a non-opacified, dilated renal pelvis and calyces in the center. The sign indicates marked loss of functional renal tissue, and if untreated, the kidney may become non-functional. Incorrect Options: Pyelonephritis (Option A): Acute pyelonephritis typically shows patchy or striated nephrograms, due to areas of inflammation and ischemia. Chronic pyelonephritis can cause scarring and cortical atrophy, but it does not produce a distinct Rim sign. Hypernephroma (Renal Cell Carcinoma) (Option B): Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) presents as an enhancing mass on imaging, often with areas of necrosis. RCC does not lead to the diffuse parenchymal thinning characteristic of the Rim sign in hydronephrosis. Polycystic Kidney Disease (Option C): Polycystic kidneys appear enlarged with multiple cysts that replace normal renal tissue. The Rim sign is not a feature of polycystic kidney disease because the cortex is not uniformly thinned in the same way as in hydronephrosis.

questions.text: Renal scan should be done in which position?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Supine. A renal scan (radionuclide renal scintigraphy) is typically performed in the supine position to ensure optimal imaging and accurate assessment of renal function, perfusion, and drainage. In the supine position, the kidneys are in their natural anatomical location, allowing for symmetrical visualization and better evaluation of renal uptake and excretion of the radiotracer (such as Tc-99m DTPA or Tc-99m MAG3). This position also ensures patient comfort and minimizes motion artifacts, leading to clearer images for diagnosing conditions like renal obstruction, scarring, or differential renal function. Incorrect Options: Prone (Option B): The prone position (lying on the stomach) is sometimes used in specific cases, such as evaluating ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction or renal transplant perfusion, but it is not the standard position for a routine renal scan. Sitting (Option C): The sitting position is not used for renal scans because it leads to shifting of abdominal organs, making it difficult to obtain stable and reproducible images of the kidneys. Left Lateral (Option D): The left lateral position is not used for renal scintigraphy, as it can cause asymmetry and misalignment, leading to inaccurate assessment of kidney function and drainage.

questions.text: A patient has calcification on AP view of right side of abdomen. In lateral view, calcification is seen to overlie the spine. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Renal stones. Renal stones (nephrolithiasis) are radio-opaque calculi that commonly appear on an AP (anteroposterior) X-ray view as calcifications in the right or left abdomen. On the lateral view, renal stones often project over the spine, as the kidneys are positioned posteriorly in the retroperitoneal space. This overlap with the spine helps differentiate renal stones from gallstones or mesenteric lymph node calcifications, which usually shift with changes in body position. Renal stones can be composed of calcium oxalate, calcium phosphate, or struvite, making them visible on plain X-rays. The presence of flank pain, hematuria, or a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) further supports the diagnosis. Incorrect Options: Gallstone (Option A): Gallstones are often radio-lucent and not typically seen on X-rays. When visible, they appear in the right upper quadrant (RUQ), near the liver and gallbladder, rather than overlying the spine. They do not remain in the same position on lateral views, as they shift with patient positioning. Calcified Mesenteric Nodes (Option B): Mesenteric lymph node calcifications result from chronic infections (e.g., tuberculosis, histoplasmosis) and appear as scattered, irregular, or clustered calcifications in the abdomen. Unlike renal stones, these do not align with the spine on a lateral view because they are located in the mesentery of the intestines, which is more anterior in the abdomen. Calcification in Vertebral Sphenoid Process (Option D): The sphenoid process refers to a bony structure in the skull, not the abdomen. Vertebral calcifications, such as those seen in degenerative spine disease, appear along the vertebral column rather than as distinct stones in the abdomen.

questions.text: Impaired renal function is assessed by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) MAG-3. MAG-3 (Mercaptoacetyltriglycine) renal scan is the best investigation to assess impaired renal function, particularly in cases of obstruction, renal perfusion, and differential renal function. MAG-3 is highly efficient in evaluating tubular function, as it is primarily excreted by the proximal renal tubules. Since tubular secretion is preserved longer than glomerular filtration in kidney disease, MAG-3 is superior to DTPA in assessing kidney function in patients with reduced renal function. MAG-3 scans provide detailed information on: - Renal perfusion (blood flow to the kidneys) - Tubular function and excretion - Obstruction (e.g., ureteropelvic junction obstruction, vesicoureteric junction obstruction) - Differential renal function (DRF) between the two kidneys This makes MAG-3 the preferred choice in conditions such as chronic kidney disease (CKD), obstructive uropathy, and renal transplant evaluation. Incorrect Options: DTPA (Diethylenetriamine pentaacetic acid) (Option A): DTPA is mainly excreted via glomerular filtration (GFR) and is used for evaluating GFR and renal perfusion. However, in cases of impaired renal function, DTPA clearance is reduced, leading to poor imaging and underestimation of function. Since MAG-3 is excreted by tubular secretion, it is preferred over DTPA for patients with compromised renal function. DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic Acid) (Option B): DMSA is used primarily for assessing renal cortical function and scarring, especially in pyelonephritis, renal scarring, or congenital abnormalities. It is not useful for measuring overall renal function or drainage, making it unsuitable for assessing impaired renal function. Iodohippurate (Hippuran) (Option C): Iodohippurate (OIH) was historically used to evaluate renal plasma flow but is now largely replaced by MAG-3, which provides better imaging quality and more accurate functional assessment.

questions.text: Bilateral spider leg sign on IVP is suggestive of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Polycystic kidney. The "spider leg sign" on Intravenous Pyelography (IVP) refers to the elongation, stretching, and splaying of calyces due to the presence of multiple cysts in polycystic kidney disease (PKD). In bilateral polycystic kidney disease, numerous cysts develop in the renal parenchyma, causing distortion and displacement of the calyces. This results in a characteristic radiological appearance resembling the legs of a spider, with calyces appearing widely spaced and stretched apart. The "spider leg sign" is highly suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), which often presents with hypertension, renal enlargement, and progressive renal failure. Incorrect Options: Hydronephrosis (Option B): While hydronephrosis can cause dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces, it usually presents with a ballooned or clubbed calyceal appearance, rather than the distinct splayed and stretched calyces seen in the spider leg sign. The dilation in hydronephrosis is due to urinary obstruction, not cystic expansion. Hypernephroma (Renal Cell Carcinoma) (Option C): Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) appears as a focal mass on imaging rather than a diffuse change in calyceal structure. It may cause distortion of the collecting system but does not produce the spider leg sign. Renal Stones (Option D): Renal stones appear as radio-opaque densities in the urinary tract, often causing calyceal blunting, obstruction, or hydronephrosis. They do not lead to the diffuse, bilateral splaying of calyces characteristic of the spider leg sign.

questions.text: IVP should be cautiously performed in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Multiple myeloma. Intravenous Pyelography (IVP) should be cautiously performed in patients with multiple myeloma because the contrast dye used in IVP can lead to acute kidney injury (AKI) in these patients. Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy associated with excessive production of monoclonal immunoglobulins, which can precipitate in the renal tubules and cause cast nephropathy (myeloma kidney). The iodinated contrast dye used in IVP can further worsen renal function by causing contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN). Additionally, dehydration is common in multiple myeloma, which increases the risk of contrast-related renal damage. Thus, IVP should be performed with extreme caution or preferably avoided in multiple myeloma patients, with alternative imaging modalities like ultrasound or MRI being preferred for renal evaluation. Incorrect Options: Bone Secondaries (Option B): Bone metastases (bone secondaries) are not a contraindication for IVP. These metastases primarily affect bone integrity, but they do not impair renal function in the same way as multiple myeloma. IVP can be safely performed unless the patient has other renal impairments. Neuroblastoma (Option C): Neuroblastoma is a pediatric malignancy that arises from the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia. While it can cause mass effect on the kidneys, it does not directly impair renal function in a way that would make IVP hazardous. CT scan with contrast is generally preferred for evaluation. Leukemia (Option D): Leukemia is a hematological malignancy that can infiltrate the kidneys, but IVP is not contraindicated unless there is severe renal dysfunction. However, in some cases, leukemic infiltration can cause acute kidney injury, and alternative imaging may be considered if renal function is compromised.

questions.text: Investigation of choice to demonstrate vesicoureteral reflux is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Contrast MCU (Micturating Cystourethrogram). Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU) is the investigation of choice for demonstrating vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). VUR is a condition where urine flows backward from the bladder into the ureters and kidneys, increasing the risk of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and renal damage. MCU is performed by catheterizing the bladder and injecting contrast dye under fluoroscopy. The patient is then asked to void (micturate), allowing visualization of any reflux of urine into the ureters. MCU provides: Real-time imaging of reflux during bladder filling and voiding Grading of reflux severity (Grade I to V) Assessment of bladder function and urethral abnormalities, which is crucial in children with recurrent UTIs or suspected congenital anomalies Because it directly demonstrates reflux, MCU is considered the gold standard for diagnosing VUR. Incorrect Options: Isotope Cystogram (Option A): Isotope cystography (radionuclide cystogram) is an alternative to MCU and involves using a radioisotope tracer instead of contrast dye. It is more sensitive for detecting reflux and has lower radiation exposure, making it useful for follow-up studies. However, it lacks anatomical detail compared to MCU and does not allow visualization of the urethra, making it less effective for initial diagnosis. Intravenous Pyelography (IVP) (Option C): IVP primarily evaluates the renal collecting system and ureters, but it is not effective in diagnosing VUR. While it may show dilated ureters or hydronephrosis as a secondary effect of reflux, it does not directly demonstrate the retrograde flow of urine, making it unsuitable for diagnosing VUR. Cystoscopy (Option D): Cystoscopy involves direct visualization of the bladder and urethra using an endoscope. While it helps assess structural abnormalities such as bladder tumors or urethral strictures, it does not show reflux because it does not evaluate urine flow dynamics. It is not useful for diagnosing VUR.

questions.text: The most important investigation for posterior urethral value is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU). Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU) is the most important investigation for diagnosing posterior urethral valves (PUV), a congenital obstruction of the male posterior urethra. PUV leads to bladder outflow obstruction, causing hydronephrosis, vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), urinary tract infections (UTIs), and renal dysfunction. MCU is performed by catheterizing the bladder and injecting contrast dye, followed by fluoroscopic imaging during bladder filling and voiding. It provides: • Direct visualization of the posterior urethral valves • Identification of urethral dilation and bladder changes • Detection of associated vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) • Assessment of bladder emptying and residual urine volume Since MCU can demonstrate the presence of a dilated posterior urethra with abrupt narrowing at the level of the valve, it is the gold standard investigation for PUV. Incorrect Options: Urethroscopy (Option A): Urethroscopy involves direct endoscopic visualization of the urethra and bladder. While it can confirm PUV and allow for treatment (e.g., valve ablation), it is an invasive procedure and is not the first-line diagnostic test. MCU is preferred for initial diagnosis. Intravenous Pyelography (IVP) (Option B): IVP evaluates the kidneys, ureters, and bladder but provides limited information about the urethra. It may show hydronephrosis or a distended bladder as secondary effects of PUV but cannot directly visualize the posterior urethral valves. Retrograde Cystogram (Option C): A retrograde cystogram assesses the bladder and ureters but does not evaluate urethral function during voiding, which is crucial in PUV diagnosis. It is mainly used for bladder trauma or vesicoureteral reflux assessment.

questions.text: The investigation of choice for imaging of urinary tract tuberculosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Computed Tomography (CT). Computed Tomography (CT) is the investigation of choice for imaging urinary tract tuberculosis (UTB) due to its superior ability to detect early and advanced renal and urinary tract involvement. UTB is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which affects the kidneys, ureters, bladder, and sometimes the prostate and seminal vesicles. CT urography provides: • Detailed visualization of renal parenchymal lesions, including cortical scarring, calcifications, and cavitations. • Detection of ureteric strictures and hydronephrosis, which are common complications. • Assessment of bladder involvement, such as thickened walls, reduced bladder capacity (thimble bladder), and irregular contours. • Identification of small non-functioning kidneys (autonephrectomy) in advanced disease. Since CT urography is more sensitive than IVP or ultrasound in detecting early changes, it is the preferred modality for diagnosing and staging urinary tract tuberculosis. Incorrect Options: Plain X-ray (Option A): A plain X-ray is not useful for early diagnosis of UTB. It may show renal calcifications in late-stage disease but lacks sensitivity for detecting soft tissue and parenchymal changes. Intravenous Urography (IVP) (Option B): IVP was historically used for UTB diagnosis, showing features like "moth-eaten calyces," strictures, or a thimble bladder, but it has been largely replaced by CT urography, which provides better anatomical details and detects earlier disease changes. Ultrasound (Option C): Ultrasound can detect hydronephrosis, renal abscesses, or parenchymal destruction, but it has limited ability to evaluate ureteric and bladder involvement. It is not the most sensitive test for UTB diagnosis compared to CT.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is wrong regarding adult polycystic kidney disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The presentation is unilateral (which is the incorrect statement). Adult Polycystic Kidney Disease (APKD), also known as Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD), is a bilateral disease characterized by the progressive development of multiple cysts in both kidneys. The disease results from mutations in the PKD1 (chromosome 16) or PKD2 (chromosome 4) genes, leading to gradual renal enlargement, renal dysfunction, and complications such as hypertension and end-stage renal disease (ESRD). Since APKD affects both kidneys (bilateral involvement), the statement that it presents unilaterally is incorrect, making Option B the correct answer. Other Options Kidneys are enlarged in size (Option A) In APKD, cysts progressively enlarge, causing significant kidney enlargement. These cysts can cause compression of normal renal tissue, leading to hypertension, hematuria, and renal failure over time. Grossly, kidneys can reach several kilograms in weight, much larger than normal kidneys. Intracranial aneurysms may be associated (Option C) APKD is associated with intracranial berry aneurysms, particularly in the circle of Willis, which can lead to subarachnoid hemorrhage. Approximately 10-15% of APKD patients have intracranial aneurysms, and screening is advised in high-risk cases (e.g., family history of aneurysms or neurological symptoms). Typically manifests in the 3rd decade (Option D) APKD remains asymptomatic in childhood and typically presents in adults (3rd–4th decade) with hypertension, hematuria, flank pain, or progressive renal insufficiency. Some patients are diagnosed incidentally during imaging for other conditions.

questions.text: The most important sign of significance of renal artery stenosis on an angiogram is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Presence of collaterals. The presence of collateral vessels on angiography is the most important indicator of significant renal artery stenosis (RAS). Collaterals form when renal blood flow is severely reduced, indicating chronic and hemodynamically significant stenosis. The development of these alternative pathways suggests that the kidney is experiencing prolonged ischemia and is attempting to compensate for reduced perfusion. Significant RAS can lead to renovascular hypertension and ischemic nephropathy, and the presence of collaterals suggests a high likelihood of renal dysfunction and potential need for intervention (angioplasty or stenting). Incorrect Options: A percentage diameter stenosis > 70% (Option A) While a >70% narrowing of the renal artery is considered severe, it does not always mean the stenosis is hemodynamically significant. Some patients with high-grade stenosis may still have adequate perfusion without ischemia. Thus, it is not the most reliable indicator of clinical significance. A systolic pressure gradient > 20 mmHg across the lesion (Option C) A pressure gradient across the stenosis helps assess hemodynamic significance, but a threshold of 20 mmHg is not universally accepted as a definitive indicator. Higher gradients (e.g., >30-40 mmHg) are considered more predictive of significant stenosis. Post-stenotic dilatation of the renal artery (Option D) Post-stenotic dilatation occurs due to turbulent blood flow beyond the stenotic segment, but it does not always correlate with functional impairment of renal blood flow. It is a common angiographic feature but not the best indicator of hemodynamic significance.

questions.text: Renal artery stenosis may occur in all of the following, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). Explanation: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) does not typically cause renal artery stenosis. PAN is a necrotizing vasculitis affecting medium-sized arteries, leading to microaneurysms, vessel rupture, and infarction rather than luminal narrowing. Renal involvement in PAN primarily presents as renal infarctions, hypertension, and renal failure due to vascular inflammation and thrombosis, rather than stenosis of the renal artery. Incorrect Options: Atherosclerosis (Option A) Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of renal artery stenosis (RAS), particularly in older patients. It results from progressive plaque buildup in the renal arteries, leading to luminal narrowing, decreased renal perfusion, and secondary hypertension. It accounts for over 90% of RAS cases. Fibromuscular Dysplasia (FMD) (Option B) FMD is the second most common cause of RAS, especially in younger women. It is a non-atherosclerotic, non-inflammatory vascular disorder, often affecting the distal renal artery and branch vessels, leading to a characteristic "string of beads" appearance on angiography. Takayasu’s Arteritis (Option C) Takayasu’s arteritis is a chronic, large-vessel vasculitis that affects the aorta and its major branches, including the renal arteries. It causes segmental stenosis, occlusions, or aneurysms, leading to renovascular hypertension and ischemic kidney damage.

questions.text: "Rugger Jersey Spine" is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Renal osteodystrophy. "Rugger Jersey Spine" is a radiological sign seen in renal osteodystrophy, a bone disorder that occurs due to chronic kidney disease (CKD). It is characterized by alternating sclerotic and lucent bands in the vertebral bodies, resembling the striped pattern of a rugby (rugger) jersey. The sclerotic bands at the superior and inferior endplates of the vertebrae are due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which leads to osteosclerosis. The lucent middle portion results from bone resorption and osteomalacia due to hypocalcemia and phosphate retention seen in CKD. Renal osteodystrophy arises from chronic kidney disease–mineral and bone disorder (CKD-MBD), in which impaired phosphate excretion and decreased calcitriol (active vitamin D) production lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism and abnormal bone metabolism. Incorrect Options: Fluorosis (Option A) Skeletal fluorosis leads to diffuse osteosclerosis but does not produce the characteristic alternating bands seen in Rugger Jersey Spine. Instead, it presents with generalized increased bone density, ligament calcifications, and spinal osteophytes. Achondroplasia (Option B) Achondroplasia is a congenital skeletal dysplasia due to a FGFR3 gene mutation. It primarily affects the growth plates, leading to short stature, spinal canal narrowing, and bullet-shaped vertebrae, but does not produce the rugger jersey pattern. Marfan's Syndrome (Option D) Marfan’s syndrome is a connective tissue disorder caused by fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene mutation. It primarily affects the aorta, eyes, and skeleton, leading to arachnodactyly, scoliosis, and joint hypermobility, but does not cause the rugger jersey sign.

questions.text: In a child, non-functioning kidney is best diagnosed by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) DTPA renogram. A DTPA (Diethylenetriamine Pentaacetic Acid) renogram is the best investigation to assess a non-functioning kidney in a child. It is a radionuclide scan that evaluates renal perfusion, function, and excretion. In a non-functioning kidney, DTPA will show little to no tracer uptake, confirming the absence of renal function. It provides quantitative assessment of each kidney’s function, which is crucial for deciding treatment options like nephrectomy. Unlike IVU, which requires good renal function for contrast excretion, DTPA renogram can detect kidneys with significantly reduced or absent function. Incorrect Options: Ultrasonography (Option A) Ultrasound is useful for detecting kidney size, hydronephrosis, cysts, and structural abnormalities but cannot assess renal function directly. A non-functioning kidney may appear normal or atrophic on ultrasound, but further functional evaluation (DTPA renogram) is required. Intravenous Urography (IVU) (Option B) IVU relies on excretion of contrast by the kidney, which means a non-functioning kidney will not be visualized. This makes IVU unreliable for assessing kidneys with severely reduced function. Creatinine Clearance (Option D) Creatinine clearance provides an overall estimation of renal function but does not determine the function of individual kidneys. It cannot differentiate between a single normal kidney compensating for a non-functioning kidney versus mild bilateral dysfunction.

questions.text: The posterior urethra is best visualized by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Voiding cystogram. A voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the best investigation for visualizing the posterior urethra because it captures the urethra during micturition, allowing for dynamic evaluation of the bladder and urethra. The posterior urethra is the proximal portion of the male urethra, including the prostatic and membranous urethra, and is best assessed when contrast medium is expelled from the bladder. VCUG is especially useful in detecting posterior urethral valves (PUV) in children, strictures, and reflux abnormalities. It provides real-time imaging of urethral anatomy, bladder function, and vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). The technique involves filling the bladder with contrast through a catheter and capturing images during voiding. Incorrect Options: Static cystogram (Option A) A static cystogram only evaluates the bladder in a filled state and does not provide information on the urethra during voiding. It is primarily used to assess bladder rupture or fistulae rather than urethral pathology. Retrograde urethrogram (Option B) A retrograde urethrogram (RUG) is excellent for imaging the anterior urethra (penile and bulbar urethra), but it does not adequately visualize the posterior urethra. It involves injecting contrast retrograde into the urethra and capturing X-rays, making it ideal for urethral strictures and trauma but not for dynamic assessment of the posterior urethra. CR cystogram (Option D) "CR cystogram" is not a standard imaging technique. If it refers to computed radiography (CR) cystogram, it would still be inferior to VCUG because it lacks the dynamic component required for assessing posterior urethral function.

questions.text: Which radionuclide is best suited for measurement of GFR?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) DTPA. Diethylenetriamine Pentaacetic Acid (DTPA) labeled with technetium-99m (Tc-99m) is the best radionuclide for measuring the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Tc-99m DTPA is freely filtered by the glomerulus without tubular reabsorption or secretion, making it an accurate marker of pure glomerular filtration. It provides quantitative assessment of GFR through plasma clearance techniques or dynamic renal scintigraphy. Compared to other methods, Tc-99m DTPA scan is non-invasive, safe, and provides real-time functional imaging of the kidneys. Incorrect Options: DMSA (Option B) Dimercaptosuccinic Acid (DMSA) is primarily used for renal cortical imaging to assess renal scarring, pyelonephritis, and differential renal function. It is not an ideal agent for measuring GFR because it binds to the renal cortex and is not excreted rapidly. Orthoiodohippurate (Option C) Iodine-131 or Iodine-123 labeled Orthoiodohippurate (OIH) is used for tubular function assessment, particularly effective renal plasma flow (ERPF), rather than GFR measurement. Since it is secreted by the proximal tubules, it does not accurately reflect glomerular filtration. EDTA (Option D) Ethylene Diamine Tetraacetic Acid (EDTA) labeled with Chromium-51 (Cr-51 EDTA) is also used for GFR measurement, but it has a longer half-life and requires multiple blood samples over time, making it less practical compared to Tc-99m DTPA.

questions.text: Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is associa­ted with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gadolinium administration in CRF. Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) is a rare but serious disorder associated with the use of gadolinium-based contrast agents (GBCAs) in patients with chronic renal failure (CRF) or severe kidney dysfunction. NSF is characterized by fibrosis of the skin, joints, and internal organs, leading to pain, thickening, and hardening of the skin, as well as reduced mobility. Gadolinium is primarily excreted by the kidneys, and in patients with CRF, impaired renal clearance results in prolonged circulation of gadolinium, increasing the risk of NSF. The exact mechanism is not fully understood, but gadolinium dissociation and deposition in tissues are believed to play a role in stimulating fibroblast proliferation. NSF can be debilitating and potentially fatal, and thus, gadolinium-based contrast agents are contraindicated or used with extreme caution in patients with severe renal impairment (eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73m²). Explanation of Incorrect Options: Genetic disease with selenium deficiency (Option B) There is no known genetic disease associated with selenium deficiency that causes nephrogenic systemic fibrosis. Selenium deficiency can lead to Keshan disease (a cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a bone and joint disorder), but it is unrelated to NSF. Chromium toxicity (Option C) Chromium toxicity primarily affects the lungs, kidneys, and liver, leading to renal failure, dermatitis, and lung cancer risk, but it does not cause NSF. NSF is specifically linked to gadolinium exposure in renal-impaired patients. HIV-associated (Option D) Although HIV can be associated with renal disease, including HIV-associated nephropathy (HIVAN), it is not a direct cause of NSF. NSF is strictly linked to gadolinium exposure in renal failure patients, not HIV infection itself.

questions.text: Bosniak classification is used for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Renal cyst. The Bosniak classification system is a widely used radiological system for categorizing renal cystic lesions based on CT scan characteristics to determine the likelihood of malignancy. The classification ranges from Bosniak I (benign simple cysts) to Bosniak IV (highly suspicious for malignancy). Bosniak I and II lesions are benign and do not require further intervention, whereas Bosniak IIF, III, and IV may require follow-up or surgical removal due to a higher risk of renal cell carcinoma. This system helps guide clinical management and treatment decisions for patients with renal cystic lesions. Incorrect Options: Acute pancreatitis (Option A) The Bosniak classification is specific to renal cysts. Acute pancreatitis is classified using systems such as the Atlanta classification, which categorizes it into mild, moderate, or severe forms based on organ failure and local complications. Mammography (Option C) Breast lesions are classified using the BI-RADS (Breast Imaging-Reporting and Data System), which assesses mammographic findings to determine malignancy risk, not the Bosniak classification. Ca endometrium (Option D) Endometrial cancer is classified using FIGO staging (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics), which categorizes tumor extent and spread. Bosniak classification is unrelated to gynecological malignancies.

questions.text: The cystographic appearance shown below is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Neurogenic bladder. A neurogenic bladder is a dysfunction of the urinary bladder due to neurological impairment, which affects normal bladder storage and emptying functions. This condition can result from spinal cord injuries, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson’s disease, diabetic neuropathy, or other neurological disorders. • On cystography, neurogenic bladder may present with an irregular, trabeculated bladder wall, reduced bladder capacity, and loss of normal bladder shape. • Depending on the type of neurogenic dysfunction, the bladder may appear small and contracted (spastic type) or large and atonic (flaccid type). • Increased post-void residual volume is commonly seen due to impaired bladder emptying. • Vesicoureteral reflux and hydronephrosis can also occur due to high intravesical pressures. Incorrect Options: Thimble bladder (Option A) - Thimble bladder is a classic cystographic finding in genitourinary tuberculosis (TB). - It appears as a small, contracted bladder with thickened walls and reduced capacity due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis. - While both thimble bladder and neurogenic bladder can appear small and irregular, thimble bladder is specifically linked to TB, not neurological dysfunction. Carcinoma urinary bladder (Option C) - Bladder cancer can lead to filling defects, irregular bladder wall thickening, and mass lesions on cystography. - It typically presents as asymmetric wall thickening with a focal or infiltrative mass, rather than the diffuse, irregular trabeculation seen in neurogenic bladder. Schistosomiasis of the bladder (Option D) - Chronic Schistosoma haematobium infection leads to calcification and fibrosis of the bladder wall. - On cystography, it appears as a calcified, contracted bladder with a "leathery" or "irregular" outline due to chronic inflammation. - Unlike neurogenic bladder, which results from neurological dysfunction, schistosomiasis is caused by parasitic infection leading to granulomatous inflammation.
